text: It is mid-afternoon, and there is a tempo and pace to the people walking, the doorman HOOTING for taxicabs, the  policemen directing traffic.
waiting at street corner for light to change.
at the end of line of pedestrians. He is looking up at th sky.

head_text.subj: MAN AND WOMAN NEXT TO HIM

text: as she follows his gaze upward.
with hundreds of gulls in it, wheeling.
as the light changes and people begin to cross. In the cr walking the other way, a man turns to look up at the whee gulls in the sky overhead. The CAMERA LOCATES:

in the crowd of pedestrians, approaching Davidson's Pet S She is a young woman in her mid-twenties, sleekly groomed exquisitely dressed, though hatless. She walks with the q sureness of the city dweller, a purposefulness in her str a mischievous grin on her face. She continues toward the  front door of a pet shop and enters.
Melanie opens the door and comes through, still looking b toward the street and skywards. The proprietor, a MRS.   MacGRUDER, comes toward her.
Hello, Mrs. MacGruder, have you ever  seen so many gulls?
Hello, Miss Daniels.
What do you suppose it is?
Mrs. MacGruder takes a look out at the sky. A puppy is  BARKING, o.s.
(shaking her head)

There must be a storm at sea. That  can drive them inland, you know. They are climbing the short flight of steps into the bird department now. The BARKING of the dog SEGUES into the cl of innumerable birds, TWEETING, TWITTERING, CAWING as Mel and Mrs. MacGruder go to the counter at the far end.  The is a circular cage in the center of the room, and the wal are lined with wire-mesh cages and smaller wooden cages s that the effect is one of being surrounded by birds, cont birds to be sure. The birds are quite beautiful, mostly e birds, small splashes of color behind the wire-mesh cages larger bursts of brilliant hue on the parrots and parakee in the bigger cages. As they walk:
I was hoping you'd be a little late,  Miss Daniels. (apologetically)
You see, he hasn't arrived yet.
You said three o'clock.
I know. Oh, I know. (she is more distressed  now)

I've been calling all morning. Oh,  you have no idea. Miss Daniels,  they're so difficult to get, really  they are. We get them from India,  you know, when they're just little  chicks, and then we have to...
Well, this one won't be a chick,  will he?
Certainly not. Oh, no. Certainly  not. This will be a full grown myna  bird. Full grown.
And he'll talk?
Well, yes, he'll talk. Well, no, no.  You'll have to teach him to talk.
Yes.
Yes. (pause)
Oh my, I suppose I should call them  again. They said three o'clock. (pause)
Maybe it's the traffic. I'll call.   Would you mind waiting?
(judiciously)
I think maybe you'd better deliver  him. Let me give you my address. (she begins taking  off her gloves)
(producing pencil and  pad)
Oh. Oh, well, all right. As Melanie starts writing:
I'm sure they're on the way, though.   Could I just call?
(with a resigned sigh)
Well, all right, but... She scurries out behind the counter and out of sight.  Me finishes writing her address and stands impatiently by th counter. She taps her teeth with the pencil.
Hello, this is Betty MacGruder at  Davidson's. (pause; accusingly)
It's past three, you know. (pause)

Well, how long do you think...? All  right, would you check it please?   Yes, I'll wait. Melanie sighs. Leaving her gloves and purse on the counte she begins wandering around the shop, still tapping her l with the pencil. There is no menace in the birds surround her. They are active and beautiful as they dart behind th bars and mesh of their cages. Off screen, the puppy begin BARKING again as the front door opens. Melanie looks up.
as he closes the entrance door behind him and starts up t steps to the bird department. He is a handsome man, about twenty-nine or thirty, well-dressed, and carrying a felt  hat.
seeing him, and then turning away to bend before the cage strawberry finches. She pokes the pencil through the mesh The birds are startled into scarlet flight.

as they pass each other in the aisle. He gives a polite l nod, and she gives a polite little smile. But as he passe her, and unknown to her, he turns for a second look -- an then vanishes behind the circular cage as he turns he cor
looking at her watch as she wanders around the other side the cage and then comes face to face with Mitch again.
I wonder if you could help me.
What?
(deliberately, and  with a touch of  hauteur)
I said I wonder if you could help  me.
a trifle annoyed by his manner at first. She is about to  inform him, if you please, that she is not a shopgirl. Bu then something rebellious flashes in her eyes and an idea comes to her.
(solicitously)
Yes, what was it you were looking  for, sir?
(deadpan)
Lovebirds.
Lovebirds, sir?
Yes. I understand there are different  varieties, it that true?
Well... yes, sir, there are.
These are for my sister... her  birthday you see. As she'll be eleven  and... well, frankly, I wouldn't  want a pair of birds that were too  demonstrative.
I understand completely, sir.
As the same time, I wouldn't want  birds that were aloof, either.
(leading him around  shop)
No, of course not.
Do you have a pair that are just  friendly?
I think so, sir. (she looks around)
Now then, let me see.
(at the finches)
Aren't these lovebirds?
No, sir, those are... redbirds.
The sign says strawberry finches.
(airily)
Yes, we call them that too. (she moves away)
Ahhh, here we are, Lovebirds... (and stops before a  cage of canaries)
Those are canaries, Miss. (pause)
Doesn't this make you feel awful?
(baffled)
Doesn't what make me...?
All these innocent little creatures  caged up like this?
Well, we can't just let them fly  around the shop, you know.
I suppose not. Is there an  ornithological reason for keeping  them in separate cages?
Oh, certainly. It's to protect the  species.
I imagine that's very important.   Especially during the moulting season.
Yes, that's a particularly dangerous  time.
Are they moulting now?
Some of them are.
How can you tell?
Well... they get a sort of hangdog  expression. CLOSE SHOT - A CAGED BIRD - MITCH'S P.O.V. The bird is wearing a distinctly hangdog expression.
Yes, I see. (pause)
About those lovebirds, Miss...
Are you sure you wouldn't like to  see a canary instead? We have some  very nice canaries this week.
All right. (he smiles)
She smiles back.
(he waits)
All right, may I see one, please?

as she realizes she is expected to take one of the canari out of the cage. She smiles feebly, glances toward the co where she expects Mrs. MacGruder to reappear momentarily, and then takes a deep breath. She opens the door to the c cage, and cautiously puts her hand into it.
(feebly)
Here, birdie. Here, birdie, birdie. One of the canaries suddenly flutters out of the cage and into the room. Melanie leaps back, startled.
Oh!  Ohhhhh!
as the canary flies frantically about the room, Melanie a Mitch in pursuit. Mrs. MacGruder appears at the counter,  finally confronted with the chaos she's been expecting al day.
What is it? Oh! Oh my, one of the  birds is loose! She joins in the chase around the room. The bird flutters to the ceiling, and then lands on the counter and watches them suspiciously.
Shhh! Shhhh! He tiptoes up to the bird, hat in hand. Quickly, he cover the bird with his hat, then reaches under to grab it.
the canary in his hand.
There we are!
Oh, good! Oh, wonderful.
as Mitch carries the canary back to the cage. He opens th door.
(putting the canary  in)
Back into your gilded cage, Melanie  Daniels.
startled.
What did you say?
(savoring this)
I was merely drawing a parallel,  Miss Daniels.
But how... how do you know my name?
(secretly)
A little birdie told me. (he smiles politely)
Good day, Miss Daniels. (he bows to Mrs.   MacGruder)
Madam. (he starts out)
Hey, wait a minute! She goes after him. Mitch turns, stops, smiles, enjoying bafflement immensely. Melanie studies him. Then:
I don't know you.
Ahhh, but I know you.
How?
We met in court.
We never met in court or anyplace  else.
That's true. I'll rephrase it. I saw  you in court.
When?
Do you remember one of your practical  jokes that resulted in the smashing  of a plate glass window?
I didn't break that window!
No, but your little prank did. The  judge should have put you behind  bars!
What are you? A policeman?
I simply believe in the law, Miss  Daniels, and I'm not too keen on  practical jokers.
What do you call your lovebird story  if not a practical...
Ahhh, but I really do want those  birds.
You knew I didn't work here. You  deliberately...
Right. I recognized you when I came  in. I thought you might like to know  what it felt like to be on the other  end of a gag. What do you think of  that, Miss Daniels?
I think you're a louse.
I am. (he tips his hat)
Good day. (to Mrs. MacGruder)
Madam. (and he goes down the  steps)
And I'm glad you didn't get your  lovebirds!
(breezily, as he goes  out)
I'll find something else. (he gives a slight  bow)
See you in court some day. The door closes. The puppy begins BARKING.
(angrily)
That... that... who was that?
I have no idea.
seething as she stares after him. Suddenly, she gets an i
going down the steps and to the front door of the shop. S looks through the glass. LONG SHOT - MITCH - MELANIE'S P.O.V. getting into his car at the curb.
looking after the car at the curb.
seeing the plate, giving a brief, determined, angry nod. begins to repeat the numbers to herself as she turns.
as she comes up the steps again and walks toward the coun MED. SHOT - MELANIE - MRS. MACGRUDER'S P.O.V. as she comes up to the counter.
Have you got a pencil?
What? Oh, yes, certainly. As Melanie begins writing:
They said the myna bird would be  here later this afternoon. If you'd  care to come back...
No, you'd better send him. May I use  your phone?
(bewildered by  everything)
Yes, certainly. (she puts phone on  counter)
(as she dials)
Do you have any lovebirds?
No, not in the shop. But I can order  them for you.
How soon?
Well... well, how soon would you  want them?
Immediately. (into phone)
Is this the Daily News? Melanie  Daniels. Would you get me the city  desk, please?
I might be able to have them by  tomorrow morning. Would that be all  right?
(with an edged anger)
That would be just fine. (into phone)
Hello, Charlie, this is Melanie. I  want you to do a favor for me. (pause)
No, this is a small one. (pause)
Pressure you? Why, Charlie darling,  would I try to pressure you?  Will  you call the Department of Motor  Vehicles for me and find out who  owns this license plate? DKQ dash  one seven six. (pause)
Yes, a California plate. (pause)
No, I'll stop up there in a little  while. Is daddy in his office? (pause)
Oh. No, no, I don't want to break in  on a meeting. Just tell him I'll see  him later. Thank you, Charlie. (she hangs up)

head_text.subj: MELANIE ICY DETERMINATION ON HER FACE.

text: Now. What time tomorrow morning?
pulling up in front of Mitch's building, the top down. Sh glances up at the address, gets out of the car, comes aro to the other side, and opens the door.
in a cage as Melanie reaches for them.
turning from the car and going into the building. She pau in the lobby, studies the names alongside the bell button
running down the list of names slowly. It stops.
her finger beside it.
CLOSE SHOT - HER GLOVED HAND the forefinger extended as s runs it down over every bell button in one column, and th does the same for the next column.
as she turns from the bells to the inner door of the lobb grabbing the knob. A BUZZ SOUNDS. She opens the door.

coming through the door and into the lobby. She walks swi toward the elevator where a well-dressed man is standing, waiting. Behind her, the inner door is BUZZING wildly wit answering BUZZES. Melanie and the man stand waiting for t elevator, silently. Behind her, the BUZZING STOPS. The  elevator doors open. The man smiles pleasantly and allows her to enter first. She does so with a small nod.  The  elevator doors close.

The birds are CHIRPING wildly in their cage. The man and  Melanie stand silently side by side. The man's eyes wande down to the bird-cage. Melanie's eyes move toward him.  S consciously, she stands with the cage of CHATTERING birds The man is dead-panned, unsmiling. The elevator stops. Th doors begin to open.

stepping out of the elevator as the doors open. The man i right behind her. She begins looking for apartment 3B. Th man is walking down the corridor beside her. She stops in front of the apartment, hesitates, hoping the man will tu the corner in the corridor. Instead, he stops at the apar just opposite. He begins fumbling in his pocket for his k He looks at Melanie.
smiling at him feebly.

The man spread change and an assortment of junk on the pa of his hand as he searches for his key. Impatiently, Mela watches him. Making a decision, she puts the birdcage dow before the door to apartment 3B, and then opens her purse
reaching into the purse for a white envelope.
written there in Melanie's handwriting: MR. MITCHELL BREN
as she props the envelope against the cage, and then hurr goes down the hallway, intent on retreat.
Miss...?  She stops, distressed.
the man at the one end, key in his hand; Melanie at the o end, near the elevator.
Is that for Mitch Brenner?
(curtly)
Yes.
He's not home.
That's all right. She presses button for the elevator.
He won't be back until Monday. I  mean, if those birds are for him....
Monday?
Yes. I don't think you should leave  them in the hall, do you?
(trapped)
Well, I... The elevator doors open.
Well, where did he go?
Bodega Bay. He goes up there every  weekend.
Bodega Bay? Where's that?
Up on the coast. About sixty miles  north of here.
Sixty... (her face falls)
Oh.
About an hour and a half on the  freeway. Or two if you take the coast  highway.
Oh.
I'd hold the birds for him, but I'm  going away myself. Someone's got to  feed them, I suppose.
(in utter despair now)
Yes. Yes, someone's got to feed them.
(apologetically)
I'm awfully sorry. He puts the key into his lock, opens the door, and goes  inside. The door closes. Melanie is alone in the hallway.
exasperated. She looks at the open elevator. She turns to look at the birds.
in their cage outside the apartment door, CHATTERING.

surrendering with a gesture of resignation. She walks dow the hall, picks up envelope and puts it in her purse, pic up the bird cage, carries it back to the elevator. The bi are COOING and CHIRPING madly.
Oh, shut up! And she steps into the elevator.

on the coast highway. It is a spectacularly beautiful day with a cloudless blue sky. The montage of SHOTS that foll should alternate between the winding, twisting road and t ocean below, and CLOSEUPS of Melanie driving with the cag birds on the seat beside her. The last shot should be a F SHOT of the car rounding a particularly sharp curve.
She turns wheel forcefully.
in the cage as the car rounds the bend. They lean to one  side as the car turns, come up straight again as the car  rounds the curve.
Car approaching Bodega Bay seen high up.
at the wheel, she glances out toward the bay.

head_text.subj: A CLUSTER OF BUILDINGS AT WATERFRONT

text: ahead, through the windshield as the car approaches.
behind the wheel, leaning forward slightly for a look at town.
through the windshield as Melanie slows her speed.
behind wheel.
on right of the road as Melanie enters the town. SLOW PAN matching car's cruise past BAKERY, SHOE REPAIR, CLEANERS, RADIO AND TELEVISION.
behind wheel.
past the gas station and beyond to the parking area and t docks, continuing Melanie's slow observation of the place
studying the town. The car turns into road by gas station

through the windshield. The car turns right. There is lif in the town now, fishermen crossing the road, women with  their hair in curlers, old ladies carrying shopping bags. This is Saturday morning, and the town -- such as it is - is alive with its inhabitants. We see them from Melanie's

pulling in, in front of the post office. Melanie opens th door and steps out. She is smartly dressed in a traveling suit and sweater. She looks up at the sign, and then walk quickly toward the front door.
enters post office.
behind cage as Melanie approaches it. He is busy filling a form of some kind, affixing stamps to it, etc. He does look up as she approaches.
through the bars of the cage.
Good morning.
(without looking up)
Morning.
I wonder if you could help me.
Try my best.
I'm looking for a man named Mitchell  Brenner.
Yep. He is still busy with his form, still does not look up.
Do you know him?
Yep.
Where does he live?
Right here. Bodega Bay.
Yes, but where?
Right across the bay there.
Where? It seems as if the Clerk will not answer her. Suddenly, h leaves the window.
through the bars, exasperated.

as she tries to peek through the bars to see where he's  vanished. A door to the left of the window opens, and the Clerk steps out. He walks a little distance as Melanie wa him, then stops, turns and looks at her surprised, as if  he'd expected her to be right behind him. He stands stock still, looking at her, saying nothing. She understands th that he wants her to follow him, and she catches up, neit speaking. They go to the front door. He opens it, looks a her, then looks out across the town and the bay. He exten his arm and points.
See where I'm pointing?
Yes?
See them two big trees across there?
Yes?
And the white house?
That's where the Brenners live.
The Brenners? Mr. and Mrs. Brenner?
Nope, just Lydia and the two kids.
The two kids?
Yep. Mitch and the little girl.
I see. How do I get down there?
Follow the road straight through  town 'til it curves off on the left.   That'll take you right around the  bay to their front door.
The front door. (pause)
Isn't there a back road I can take?
Nope. That's the road. Straight  through town, stay on your left,  right around the bay to the front  door.
You see, I wanted to surprise them.
Mmmm.
I didn't want to come right down the  road, where they could see me.
Mmmm.
It's a surprise, you see.
Mmmmmm. (long pause)
'Course, you could get yourself a  boat, cut right across the bay with  it. The Brenners got a little dock  there you could tie up at. If that's  what you wanted to do.
Where would I get a boat?
Down at the dock by the Tides  Restaurant. Ever handled an outboard  boat?
(looking at him)
Of course.
(looks back at her)
D'you want me to order one for you?
(surprised)
Thank you.
What name?
Daniels.
Okay. He nods briefly and goes inside. Melanie looks across the bay.

smiling. She gets a new idea. She reaches into her purse the envelope. She looks at the envelope, then tears it up and stuffs the torn envelope into her handbag. She turns  back toward the post office.
as Melanie approaches the Clerk's window. He is still bus still does not look up.
I wonder if you could tell me...
Yep?
The little girl's name.
The little Brenner girl?
Yes.
Alice, I think. (he turns, shouts to  someone in rear)
Harry, what's the little Brenner  girl's name?
(shouting)
What?
(shouting)
The little Brenner girl.
(shouting)
Lois!
(shouting)
It's Alice, ain't it?
(shouting)
No, it's Lois!
(to Melanie)
It's Alice.
Are you sure?
Well, I ain't positive, if that's  what you mean.
I need her exact name, you see.

That case, I tell you what you do.   You go straight through town 'til  you see a little hotel on your left  there. Not the motel, that's the  other end of town. This is the hotel.  Now you take a right turn there, you  got that?
Yes?

Near the top of the hill, you'll see  the school and right behind it, the  church. You head for the school.   Now just past the school, you'll see  a little house with a red mail box.   That's where Annie Hayworth lives,  she's the school teacher. You ask  her about the little Brenner girl.
Thank you.
Yep. (pause)
Could save yourself a lot of trouble.  Her name's Alice for sure.
Can I have the boat in about twenty  minutes? The Clerk nods.
How much for the phone calls?
(brushing this aside)
It's nothing.
grinning, as she makes for the door and EXITS.
getting into the car and slamming the door.
LONG SHOT (MATTE) - MELANIE'S CAR turning in school road.
passing the school and pulling up outside the teacher's h
with the name "Hayworth" on it. PULL BACK to reveal:

passing the mail box and going up the walk to the front d The house is a two-story frame with steps leading to the  front door. There are white curtains in every window of t house, and a sign in the window to the left of the doorwa advises, ROOM TO LET. Melanie rings the doorbell.
waiting. She RINGS the bell again:
(shouting)
Yes? Who is it?
Me!
Who's me?

walking along the porch of the house. The walk in front o the house is lined with beautifully planted and cared-for flowers. ANNIE HAYWORTH comes round from the back of the  house as Melanie reaches the corner. She is a woman of th two, tall, big-boned, with a strong beautiful face.  Her  hair is disarrayed at the moment, and she is dressed for garden, wearing slacks and a loose-fitting sweater, and e stained gloves. But there is something about her, a feeli of expansive comfort, rather than sloppiness.
Miss Hayworth?
Yes?
I'm Melanie Daniels. I'm sorry to  bother you, but...
She is puzzled by Melanie who, exquisitely dressed and  groomed, seems singularly out of place in Bodega Bay. She studies her openly.
Yes?
The man at the post office sent me.   He said you'd know the name of the  little Brenner girl.
Cathy?
The one who lives in the white house  across the bay?
That's the one. Cathy Brenner.
(smiling)
They seemed sure it was either Alice  or Lois.
Which is why the mail in this town  never gets delivered to the right  place. (She takes out package  of cigarettes, offers  one to Melanie)
Did you want to see Cathy about  something?
taking cigarette, hesitating.
Well... not exactly.
studying her, thinking she understands.
Are you a friend of Mitch's?
No, not really.
There is an awkwardness here. Annie wants to know more. S puffs on the cigarette, smiles, tries a friendly approach
I've been wanting a cigarette for  the past twenty minutes, but I  couldn't convince myself to stop.   This 'tilling of the soil' can get a  little compulsive, you know.
It's a lovely garden.
Thank you. It gives me something to  do with my spare time. (pause)
There's a lot of spare time in Bodega  Bay. (another pause)
Did you plan on staying long?
No. Just a few hours.
You're leaving after you see Cathy?
Well... something like that. (pause)
I'm sorry. I don't mean to sound so  mysterious.
Actually, it's none of my business. There is a pause. Melanie, by her silence, affirms that i is none of Annie's business.
(putting out cigarette)
I'd better get on my way. Thank you  very much.
Not at all. They begin walking toward the car.
(still curious)
Did you drive up from San Francisco?
Yes.
It's a nice drive. (pause)
Is that where you met Mitch?
(hesitating, then)
Yes.
I guess that's where everyone meets  him.
as she gets in behind the wheel. Annie's remark is not lo on her, and a quick look of sudden understanding crosses face.
Now you sound a bit mysterious, Miss  Hayworth.
as Annie leans over the seat.
Do I? (she shakes her head,  smiles wistfully)
No, I'm an open book, I'm afraid. (pause)
Or maybe a closed one. (she smiles again,  sees the lovebirds)
Pretty. What are they?
Lovebirds. Taking this as a further indication of Melanie's relation with Mitch:
Mmm. (pause)
Well, good luck, Miss Daniels.
Thank you. She nods pleasantly, starts the car, pulls away.
watching the car, a look of sad resignation on her face.
coming out of Brinkmeyer's General Store, carrying a smal paper bag, walking toward her car out front. The CAMERA  FOLLOWS her as she gets in. She opens her purse and reach in for the paper bag.
She pulls out a birthday card from the paper bag.
reaching into her purse again for a fountain pen. She uns the cap, braces the card on her closed purse.
Happy Birthday, the usual rhyming sentiments. The pen wri To Cathy
crossing the highway down into the parking area behind th Tides, close to the docks.

She gets out of the car and walks onto one of the docks, bird cage in her hand. Melanie approaches a waiting fishe She asks for her boat. The fisherman nods. He leads her t the dock and the waiting boat.  She gets into the outboar motorboat, the fisherman helping her. He hands down the  lovebirds in their cage.
pulling away from the dock, heading across the bay.
and the wide expanse of the bay, as it heads on a direct  course for the house on the other side.
Another spectacular SHOT of the small boat.

coming head-on toward CAMERA, Melanie at the tiller. She  cuts the motor. The motor drifts to a stop. The bay is si except for the cry of the gulls. LONG SHOT - THE BRENNER HOUSE - MELANIE'S P.O.V. There is not a sign of activity as the boat drifts just a little closer. As Melanie watches, the front door opens a a woman comes out, walks to a red pickup truck, starts th engine. A little girl comes out of the house, goes to the truck, gets in. The woman shouts something to a man -- Mi Brenner, probably, though it is difficult to tell from th distance -- and he comes over to the truck. The truck grinds into gear, goes around the turnabout, an heads down the road away from the farm, a huge cloud of d behind it. The farm is still again. Mitch stands looking  after the truck for a moment, and then begins walking up  toward the barn in the distance.
watching, biting her lip.
Mitch reaching the barn and entering. Silence.
watching, waiting.
Not a sign of life.
picking up paddle from deck, beginning to paddle in towar dock.
edging in toward the dock. Closer, closer, Melanie puts d the paddle. The boat drifts in.

leaping ashore, tying up the boat, reaching down for the  cage. She climbs onto the dock and approaches the CAMERA  until she is in WAIST SHOT. The CAMERA STARTS to RECEDE i front of her as she walks forward.
The barn door closed, still no sign of Mitch.
Coming off the dock and onto the lawn, the CAMERA still  RETREATING in front of her. She makes her way carefully a the lawn, glancing toward the barn, carrying the bird cag

as the door opens. Melanie ENTERS quickly, and closes the door behind her. She glances around for a moment, getting her bearings. The house is silent.
entering the dining room. Hastily, she puts the cage on t dinning room table, props the card up against it, then gl through the lace curtains on the dinning room window.

as before. EXT. BRENNER HOUSE - WAIST SHOT - MELANIE - MOVING P.O.V. as the front door opens and Melanie EMERGES. CAMERA PANS FOLLOWS her back down front walk. Melanie glances over he shoulder toward the barn. EXT. BARN - MOVING P.O.V. Mitch has not emerged.

as she looks toward the house and barn. She starts to duc down. EXT. BARN - MELANIE'S P.O.V. as Mitch EMERGES from the barn and goes toward the house. goes INSIDE.
peering over the stern of the boat. EXT. HOUSE - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch dashes OUT of the front door and looks around.
as she watches Mitch. MELANIE'S P.O.V. as Mitch runs back INTO the house.
peering over stern of the boat. MITCH - MELANIE'S P.O.V. as he EMERGES from the front door and raises binoculars.
as he looks towards Melanie's boat through the binoculars The Bay is reflected in the glass.

He is smiling with amused recognition; he lowers the  binoculars and dashes OUT OF FRAME.
The CAMERA IS MOVING WITH her as she looks toward Mitch.
Mitch is running for his car. The car door SLAMS. The ENG STARTS. The car practically leaps out of the driveway.
as she watches the car race along the shore. LONG SHOT - CAR - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch's car racing along the shore.
She looks off RIGHT toward car. CAR - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch's car racing along the shore road, turns inland at  Keesport.
Melanie looks CAMERA RIGHT, her eyes slowly turn CAMERA L CAR - MELANIE'S MOVING P.O.V. Mitch's car races past wrecked ferry boat.
Her head continues to turn CAMERA LEFT. She looks off and sees: LONG SHOT - THE DOCK - MELANIE'S MOVING P.O.V. moves forward slower. Mitch drives onto dock, gets out of the car and stands waiting.
partially posing for Mitch, her hair blowing in the wind, her head tilted back, a smile on her face.
swooping down from UPPER LEFTHAND CORNER OF FRAME TO LOWE
as gull strikes the back of her head. She recoils and loo up with shock and pain. GULL - MELANIE'S P.O.V. The gull soars away from LOWER RIGHTHAND corner of frame UPPER LEFT.
reacting to the sudden attack and looking after receding  gull. Blood is starting down her temple from her hair.
as the boat comes closer. The boat drifts in toward a sec boat tied up at the dock. Mitch crosses the docked boat,  leaps into Melanie's boat.
in the boat.
That was the damndest thing I ever  saw.
What made it...
It deliberately came down at you -- you're bleeding...

a thin line of blood trickling from the cut on top of her head, down onto her forehead and cheek. She seems dazed. She shakes her head in answer to him, then touches the to of her head, looks at her bloody fingers, and then nods  weakly.
concerned.
Come on, let's take care of that.
as they climb onto it. A fisherman standing by looks at  Melanie curiously.
What happened, Mitch?
(over his shoulder)
A gull hit her.
A what? The CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they walk across the parking a behind the Tides, and to the closest office. Mitch tries door knob. The door is locked.

head_text.subj: SIGN ON DOOR OUT TO LUNCH TWO SHOT

text: as he tries door of next office. It, too, is locked.

Come on, we'd better go up to the  restaurant. They walk quickly up the slope to the Tides, establishing gas station across the road, the collection of stores  opposite, the cars pulling in and out. Mitch opens the do for her, and they ENTER.

This is a small neighborhood restaurant, with the feeling a local hangout. There are fishermen lounging at the bar, and a teenage boy playing one of the pinball machines. Tw ladies in housedresses, with their hair in curlers, are  sitting at one of the booths, having coffee. The rear wal of the restaurant is almost all window, looking out over bay and the parking area below. A television set over the bar is going. The shots and horsehoof beats of an old Wes movie should be HEARD muted throughout following.  DEKE  CARTER, who owns the restaurant with his wife, alternates his attention between serving his customers and watching Western. He looks up immediately when Mitch and Melanie E
Mitch and Melanie coming over to it.
Deke, have you got a first aid kit  back there?
(instantly alarmed)
What happened?
Young woman cut herself.
Shall I call the doctor?
(accepting the first  aid kit)
I don't think it's that serious.   You want to sit up here? Melanie climbs onto the stool.
You cut yourself outside, Miss?
Stop worrying, Deke. She was in a  boat. He is rummaging around in the kit.
I had a man trip and fall in the  parking lot once, sued me before I  could bat an eyelash.
I don't think Miss Daniels is going  to sue anybody.
(doubtfully)
Well, you're the lawyer. (goes to other end of  bar)
as he unscrews cap from bottle of peroxide.
What's that?
Just some peroxide. I want to clean  out the cut. He pours peroxide onto a gauze pad and begins swabbing th cut. They are silent for several seconds. Then:
So you're a lawyer.
That's right. What are you doing in  Bodega Bay?
Do you practice here?
No, San Francisco. What are you...?
What kind of law?
Criminal.
Is that why you'd like to see everyone  behind bars?
Not everyone, Miss Daniels.
Only violators and practical jokers.
That's right. As he swabs cut.
Ouch!
I'm sorry. (pause)
What are you doing up here?
Didn't you see the lovebirds?
You came all the way up here to bring  me those birds?
To bring your sister those birds.   You said it was her birthday.   Besides, I was coming up anyway.
What for?
To see a friend of mine. (she winces)
Will you please be careful?
I'm sorry. (pause)
Who's your friend?
Why... (pause, stymied)
Yes?
(blurting the only  name she knows)
Annie. Annie Hayworth.
Well, well, small world. Annie  Hayworth.
(realizing this was a  mistake)
Yes.
How do you know Annie?
(the lie getting deeper)
We... we went to school together.   College.
Did you! Imagine that! How long will  you be staying?
Just a few... just a day or two...  the weekend.
I think we'll have to shave the hair.  Deke, have you got a razor?
(pulling away)
Oh, no you don't!
It's still bleeding a little. Here,  let me put this on. He takes up a tiny Band-Aid and, tearing the gauze off, s

Bend your head down. This little  Band-Aid won't show. He presses the tiny Band-Aid over the cut. Melanie takes mirror from her handbag and, bending her head down, looks it. She covers her hair over it as Mitch says:
So you came up to see Annie, huh?
Yes.
I don't believe you. (grins)
I think you came up to see me.
Why would I want to see you, of all  people?
(shrugging)
I don't know. But it seems to me you  must have gone to a lot of trouble  to find out who I was, and where I  lived and...
It was no trouble at all. I simply  called my father's paper. Besides, I  was coming up here anyway, I already  told you...
(grinning)
You like me, huh?
I loathe you. You have no manners.   And you're arrogant and conceited  and... I wrote you a letter about  it, in fact, but I tore it up.
What did it say?
None of your business. (pause)
Am I still bleeding? She lowers her head.
Can't see a thing.
I can't say I like your seagulls  much, either. I come all the way up  here to...
But you were coming up anyway,  remember?
I was! And all I get for my pains is  a... a... a hole in the head!
(grinning)
Right next to the one you already  had.
(angrily)
Look, Mr. Brenner...
Mitch? They turn toward the door.

closing the door behind her, coming toward the bar. She i woman in her late forties, attractive, wearing shirt, blo cardigan sweater, low heels. There is nothing agrarian-lo about her. She speaks with the quick tempo of the city  dweller, and there is lively inquiry in her eyes.
(puzzled)
I thought I saw your car. What are  you doing in town?
(rising to greet her)
I had to acknowledge a delivery. (grins)
Mother, I'd like you to meet...
A what?
(continuing)
Melanie Daniels. Melanie, my mother.
Her eyebrows raising ever so slightly, not in displeasure but simply in enormous curiosity as she acknowledge the  introduction.
How do you do, Miss Daniels? (to Mitch)
Acknowledge a what?
A delivery, Mother. Miss Daniels  brought some birds from San Francisco. Lydia thinks she understands. This is one of Mitch's San  Francisco chippies.
Oh. I see.
For Cathy. For her birthday. By the  way, where is she?
Across at Brinkmeyer's.
Miss Daniels is staying for the  weekend. In fact, I've already invited  her to dinner tonight.
turning to him in surprise, beginning to shake her head.
After all, you did go to the trouble  of bringing up those birds.
I'm sorry. I couldn't possibly...
You did say birds?
Yes, lovebirds. We couldn't let you...
(understanding  completely now)
Lovebirds, I see.
...get away without thanking you in  some small way. After all, you haven't  even met Cathy and you are staying  for the weekend...
Yes, but...
You are, aren't you?
Certainly, but...
Then it's settled. What time is  dinner, Mother?
Seven o'clock, same as usual.
I'll pick you up, Miss Daniels.   Where are you staying?
With... with Annie, of course.
Of course, how stupid of me. A quarter  to seven, will that be all right?
Annie... Annie may have made other  plans. I'll have to see. Besides, I  can find my own way.
You're sure now? You won't hire a  boat or anything?
I'm sure.
Seven o'clock then.
Maybe.
grinning.
We'll be waiting. How's your head  now?
Lydia looks at Mitch inquiringly.
(with an overwarm  smile)
It's nothing, Mrs. Brenner. A gull  hit me, that's all. Lydia stares at her doubtfully.
Melanie is standing on the front steps, a paper bag in he hands. She rings the doorbell. The ROOM TO LET sign is st in the window. The door suddenly opens.
(surprised)
Oh, hi! (pause)
Did you find her all right?
Yes, I did. There is a long awkward pause. Annie smiles expectantly a Melanie. Melanie seems hesitant.
I was wondering...
Yes?
That sign. (pause)
Do you think I could have the room  for a single night?
Well, I'd really hope to rent it  for...
I would appreciate it. I've tried  everywhere in town, and they're all  full.
(after a pause)
Sure. You can have it. (smiles)
Where's your bag? In the car? Melanie holds up the paper bag. Annie looks at it and the smiles.
It's utilitarian, I'll say that for  it.
(smiling)
I just picked up some things for the  night at the general store. You see,  I hadn't planned on spending much  time here.

Yes, I know. Did something unexpected  crop up? There is a moment where both women look at each other... When Melanie answers, it is abrupt and a trifle cold -- s is again telling Annie to mind her own business.
Yes. (pause)
May I use your phone? I'd like to  call home. There is another moment where Annie appraises Melanie's  attitude, and then accepts it. She suddenly smiles warmly
Why don't you come in then?  I was  just about to mix a martini. She is about to lead Melanie into the house when they bot hear a SOUND overhead. They turn to look skyward.
flying in beautiful precise formation against the sky.
(shaking her head)
Don't they ever stop migrating? But Melanie is watching the sky and the birds with a curi serious expression.
LONG SHOT - THE APPROACH ROAD to the Brenner house. Melan car is driving along the shore. Behind her, the sky is st with sunset. There are gulls on the bay, cawing into the  silence.
as it pulls into the Brenner yard.

reaching up for the rear view mirror, tilting it to exami her lipstick, touching the edge of her mouth with one han She gets out of the car, CAMERA FOLLOWING her to the hous She climbs the porch steps, KNOCKS on the door. There is answer. Puzzled, she begins walking back into the yard. I the distance, she sees Mitch, Lydia and Cathy coming from behind the chicken sheds. She raises her arm in greeting.
(calling)
Hi!
in the distance. Mitch and Cathy raise their arms.
(excitedly)
Hi! (she breaks into a  trot toward Melanie)
CLOSE SHOT - CATHY as she approaches. She is an eleven-ye old child, clear-eyed, bright, uninhibited, wearing a shi and blouse, her hair cropped close to her head. She hesit for just a moment.
Miss Daniels?
Yes? And Cathy flings herself into Melanie's arms, almost knoc her off her feet, hugging her fiercely.
They're beautiful! They're just what  I wanted! Is there a man and a woman?  I can't tell which is which.
Well, I suppose...
(coming up)
Hi. Annie had no plans, huh? I'm  glad you came. Are you hungry?
Famished.
Dinner's just about ready. (explaining)
We were out back looking at the  chickens. Something seems to be wrong  with them.
(going toward house)
There's nothing wrong with those  chickens, Mitch. I'm going to call  Fred Brinkmeyer right now.
(as they follow into  house)
I don't know what good that'll do. (aside to Melanie)
Chickens won't eat.
as they ENTER, CAMERA FOLLOWING them throughout into dini room where Lydia dials phone, talking to Mitch all along.
He sold the feed to me, didn't he?
Caviat emptor, Mother. Let the buyer  beware.
Whose side are you on?
I'm simply quoting the law.
Never mind the law. Cathy, you can  start serving the soup. She has finished dialing now, is waiting while the phone  RINGS.
This won't take a minute, Miss Dan... (into phone)
Hello, Fred? This is Lydia Brenner.   I didn't interrupt your dinner, did
(pause)
Fred, that feed you sold me is no  good. (pause)
The chicken feed. The three bags I  brought.
holding the telephone.
Well, it's just no good. The chickens  won't eat it. (pause)

They're always hungry, Fred. I opened  one of the sacks when I got home,  and I poured it out for them, and  they wouldn't touch it. Now you know  chickens as well as I do, and when  they won't eat, there's just something  wrong with what they're being fed,  that's all. (pause)
No, they're not fussy chickens. (pause)
Who? What's he got to do with it? (pause)
Fred, I don't care how much feed you  sold him. My chickens... (pause)
He did? Dan Fawcett? (pause)
This afternoon? (pause)
Well, that only proves what I'm  saying. The feed you sold us is... (pause)
Oh. Oh, I see. Uh-huh. Uh-huh.  Uh- huh. Maybe I ought to go over to see  him. You don't think there's something  going around, do you? (pause)
No, never. (pause)
No, Fred, they don't seem sick at  all. They just won't eat. (pause)
Mmmm. Mmmmm. Well, I'll try to get  over to Dan's farm.  Maybe he'll...  mmmmm... mmmmm... all right, Fred,  thanks. (she hangs up, puzzled)
as Lydia comes to the table. Mitch and Melanie are sittin opposite each other in the center chairs. Cathy is servin the last bowl of soup.
(as she sits)
He got a call from Dan Fawcett a  little while ago. His chickens won't  eat, either.
It's what you said, Mom. Mr.   Brinkmeyer's feed is no good.
(slowly)
No, Cathy. He sold Mr. Fawcett a  different brand. (extremely worried)
You don't think they're getting sick,  do you, Mitch?
her eyes troubled as she picks up her napkin.

The meal is over. The lovebirds in their hanging cage hav been covered for the night. In the b.g. Mitch and Lydia a carrying the stacked dishes to the kitchen. In the f.g.   Cathy and Melanie are by a small upright piano. Melanie i playing a Debussy Arabesque: She picks up a cigarette fro the ashtray now and again to take a puff.
I still don't understand how you  knew I wanted lovebirds.
Your brother told me.
(as she goes into  kitchen)
Then you knew Mitch in San Francisco,  is that right?
No, not exactly.
Mitch knows lots of people in San  Francisco. Of course, they're mostly  hoods.
(from the kitchen)
Cathy!
Well, Mom, he's the first to admit  it. (to Melanie)
He spends half his day in the  detention cells at the Hall of  Justice.
(coming from kitchen)
In a democracy, Cathy, everyone is  entitled to a fair trial. Your  brother's practice...
Mom, please, I know all the democracy  jazz. They're still hoods. (to Melanie)
He's got a client now who shot his  wife in the head six times. Six times,  can you imagine it? (she starts for living  room)
I mean, even twice would be overdoing  it, don't you think?
(to Mitch as he carries  load of dishes out)
Why did he shoot her?
He was watching a ball game on  television.
What?
His wife changed the channel. He GOES INTO kitchen.
Melanie interrupts her playing to take another puff at he cigarette.
Is smoking fun?
Oh, I suppose so.
Could I have a puff?
I don't think your mother would like  that.
Just a little one.
They both glance conspiratorially toward the kitchen.   Quickly, Melanie extends the cigarette. Quickly, Cathy ta a small puff.
(delighted)
Why, it's just like air, isn't it? (determined)
When I grow up, I'm gonna smoke like  a chimney! I'll be eleven tomorrow,  you know.
I know.
Are you coming to my party?
I don't think so. (seeing the child's  face)
I have to get back to San Francisco.
Don't you like us?
(touching her hair)
Darling, of course I do!
Don't you like Bodega Bay?
I don't know yet.
Mitch likes it very much. He comes  up every weekend, you know, even  though he has his own apartment in  the city. He says San Francisco is  just an ant hill at the foot of a  bridge.
(smiling)
I guess it does get a little hectic  at times.
If you do decide to come, don't say  I told you about it. It's supposed  to be a surprise party. Melanie laughs.

You see, they've got this whole  complicated thing figured out where  I'm going over to Michele's for the  afternoon, and Michele's mother is  going to say she has a headache and  would I mind very much if she took  me home. Then, when we get back here,  all of the kids'll jump out! (pause)
Won't you come? Won't you please  come?
shaking her head, glancing toward the kitchen.
I don't think so, Cathy.
Mitch is helping her as she loads the dishwasher.
She's a charming girl, isn't she,  Mitch?
Yes, very.
And certainly pretty.
Yes.
How long have you known her?
I told you. We met yesterday.
In a bird shop.
Yes.
She was selling birds.
No. I only led her into believing I  believed she was... Mother, it's  really very complicated.
But she did buy the lovebirds and  then brought them all the way...
Mother, where did you go to law  school?
(laughing)
Forgive me. I suppose I'm just  naturally curious about a girl like  that. (pause)
She's very rich, isn't she?
I suppose so. Her father owns a big  newspaper in San Francisco.
You'd think he could manage to keep  her name out of print. She's always  mentioned in the columns, Mitch.
I know, Mother.
She is the one who jumped into that  fountain in Rome last summer, isn't  she?
Yes, Mother.
Perhaps I'm old-fashioned. (pause)
I know it was supposed to be very  warm there, Mitch, but... well...   actually... well, the newspaper said  she was naked.
I know, Mother.
It's none of my business, of course,  but when you bring a girl like that  to...
Mother?
(looking up)
Yes?
I think I can handle Melanie Daniels  by myself.
Well... (she sighs)
So long as you know what you want,  Mitch.
I know exactly what I want, Mother.
as Mitch and Melanie cross it to her car. A wind is blowi off the water, and high fast clouds are scudding across t face of the moon.
You'll be able to find your way back,  won't you?
Oh, yes.
Will I be seeing you again?
San Francisco's a long way from here.
I'm in San Francisco five days a  week. With a lot of time on my hands.  I'd like to see you. (he grins)
Maybe we could go swimming or  something. Mother tells me you like  to swim.
How does Mother know what I like to  do?
I guess she and I read the same gossip  columns.
Oh. That. Rome.
Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get  along very...
In case you're interested, I was  pushed into that fountain.
Without any clothes on?
With all my clothes on!  The newspaper  that ran the story happens to be a  rival of my father's paper.  Anything  they said...
You were just a poor, innocent victim  of circumstance, huh?
I'm neither poor nor innocent, but  the truth of that particular...
The truth is you were running around  with a pretty wild crowd...
Yes, but...
...who didn't much care for propriety  or convention or...
Yes.
...the opinions of others, and you  went right along with them, isn't  that the truth?
Yes, that's the truth. But I was  pushed into that fountain, and that's  the truth, too.
Sure. Do you really know Annie  Hayworth?
No. (pause)
At least, I didn't until I came up  here.
So you didn't go to school together.
No.
And you didn't come up here to see  her.
No.
You were lying.
Yes, I was lying.
Did you really write a letter to me?   Or was that a lie, too?
I wrote the letter.
What did it say?
It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think  you need those lovebirds, after all.   They may help your personality."  That's what it said.
But you tore it up.
Yes.
Why?
Because it seemed stupid and foolish.
Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!
I told you what happened in Rome!
Do you expect me to believe...?
I don't give a damn what you believe! Angrily she gets into the car, is about to slam the door  when Mitch catches it in his hands.
I'd still like to see you.
Why?
I think it could be fun.
pulling the door shut.
That might have been good enough in  Rome last summer. But it's not good  enough now.
It is for me.
But not for me.
What do you want ?
(angrily sarcastic)
I thought you knew! I want to go  through life laughing and beautiful  and jumping into fountains naked!   Good night!
as it pulls away. Mitch yanks his hands back from the doo
as he watches the car leave.
The car turns the bend and disappears. Empty road. Only t long line of telephone poles and wires and... something  strange on the wires.
His attention caught by the poles and wires.
Hundreds of birds sitting on them.
standing and watching. A wind blows off the water. He shi suddenly, turns up his collar, and heads for the house.
In an easy chair, reading. She is wearing a robe and smok absorbed in her book. She turns when she hears the front  DOOR OPENING.
Miss Daniels? Is that you?
Yes. Annie rises to greet her. As Melanie ENTERS THE SHOT:
Hi. (seeing her face)
Is something wrong? Is that cut  beginning to bother you?
(touching her head)
No, it's not the cut that's bothering  me.
(concerned)
Would you like some brandy?
If you have some, I'd...
I'll get it, sit down, Miss Daniels.   Do you want a sweater or something?   A quilt? As Annie gets the brandy:
No, thank you. (pause)
Won't you call me Melanie?
All right. (she smiles)

MED. SHOT - MELANIE sitting, tucking her legs up under he She is disturbed by her conversation with Mitch and, in f by the way this entire trip has worked out. Annie brings the glass of brandy, and she takes it gratefully.
Thank you.
(sitting opposite her)
It gets a little chilly here at night  sometimes. Especially if you're over  near the bay. Melanie nods and sips at the brandy. There is a long paus
Well, how'd your evening go? Melanie shrugs.
Did you meet Lydia? Melanie nods.
Or would you rather I changed the  subject?
(with a tired smile)
I think so.
(nodding)
How do you like our little hamlet?
I despise it.
(laughing)
Well, I don't suppose it offers much  to the casual visitor. Unless you're  thrilled by a collection of shacks  on a hillside. It takes a while to  get used to.
Where are you from originally, Annie?
San Francisco.
How'd you happen to come here?
Oh, someone invited me up for the  weekend a long time ago. There is an awkward pause. Annie shrugs.
Look, I see no reason for being coy  about this. It was Mitch Brenner. Melanie nods.
I guess you knew that, anyway.
I suspected as much.
You needn't worry. It's over and  done with. A long time ago.
Annie -- there's nothing between  Mitch and me.
Isn't there? (she shrugs)
Maybe there isn't. Maybe there's  never anything between Mitch and any  girl.
What do you mean?
I think I'll have some of that, too. (she pours brandy,  drinks, sighs)
I was seeing quite a lot of him in  San Francisco, you know. (she smiles weakly)
And then, one weekend, he asked me  up to meet Lydia.
When was this?
Four years ago. Of course, that was  shortly after his father died.  Things  may be different now.
Different?
With Lydia. (pause)
Did she seem a trifle distant?
(smiling)
A trifle.
Then maybe it isn't different at  all. You know, her attitude nearly  drove me crazy. I simply couldn't  understand it.
When I got back to San Francisco I  spent days trying to figure out just  what I'd done to displease her.
And what had you done?
Nothing! I simply existed. So what  was the answer? A jealous woman,  right? A clinging possessive mother. (she shakes her head)
Wrong. With all due respect to  Oedipus, I don't think that was the  case at all.
Then what was it?
Lydia liked me, you see. That was  the strange part of it. In fact, now  that I'm no longer a threat, we're  very good friends.
Then why did she object to you?
Because she was afraid.
Afraid you'd take Mitch?
Afraid I'd give Mitch.
I don't understand.
Afraid of any woman who'd give Mitch  the only thing Lydia can give him -- love.
Annie, that adds up to a jealous,  possessive woman.
No, I don't think so. She's not afraid  of losing her son, you see.  She's  only afraid of being abandoned.
Someone ought to tell her she'd be  gaining a daughter.
She already has a daughter.
What about Mitch? Didn't he have  anything to say about this?
(apologetically)
I can understand his position. He  went through a lot with Lydia after  his father died. He didn't want to  risk going through it all over again.
I see.
So it ended. Not immediately, of  course. I went back to San Francisco,  and I still saw Mitch every now and  then... but we both knew it was  finished.
Then what are you doing here in Bodega  Bay?
You get straight to the point, don't  you?
I'm sorry. Forgive me.

No, that's all right, I don't mind.   I came up here for two reasons. To  begin with, I was bored with my job  in San Francisco. I was teaching at  a private school there... well, you  know, you probably went to one  yourself.
I did.

Then you know. Little girls in brown  beanies. Deadly. Here I have a life.  I'll go into that classroom on Monday  morning, and I'll look out at twenty- five upturned little faces, and each  of them will be saying, 'Yes, please  give me what you have.' (pause)
And I'll give them what I have. I  haven't got very much, but I'll give  them every ounce of it. To me, that's  very important. It makes me want to  stay alive for a long long time. (she sighs)
That's the first reason.
And the second?
(simply)
I wanted to be near Mitch. (pause)
It was over, and I knew it, but I  wanted to be near him, anyway. (she smiles)

You see, I still like him a hell of  a lot. That's rare, I think. I don't  want to lose his friendship... ever. There is a moment of silence. Into the silence, the TELEP shrills. Annie hesitates a moment, and then goes to answe it.
at the phone.
Hello?  Oh, hello. No, no, I wasn't  asleep. What is it? (pause)
Yes, just a little while ago. Sure,  hold on. (she turns to Melanie)
It's Mitch. For you.
as they stare at each other across the room, Melanie  hesitating.

He's waiting. Melanie rises and goes to the phone. The CAMERA FOLLOWS A to the wing chair in the foreground and stays on her  throughout following, recording her reactions as Melanie  talks to Mitch in the background. Annie is not devastated by this call, and yet there is a  wistfulness to her expression as she realizes she may fin and irrevocably be losing Mitch to another girl.
(at phone; coolly)
Hello? Yes, this is Melanie. Fine,  thank you. No, no trouble at all.  I  simply followed the road. It's a  very bright night. (pause)
What?  Oh. Well, there's no need to  apologize. I can understand... (pause; she listens)
Well... (she listens again)
That's very kind of you. No, I'm not  angry. (she listens)
I couldn't. I'm afraid I have to get  back to San Francisco. (pause)
No, I wouldn't want to disappoint  Cathy, but... (pause)
I see. (she is warming)
I see. Well, if you really... (pause)
All right. Yes, I'll be there. (pause)
Good night, Mitch. She hangs up and looks at Annie in embarrassment.
He wants me to go to Cathy's party  tomorrow afternoon. (pause)
I said I would.
I'll be going, too, to help out. It  should be fun, Melanie.
It seems so pointless. (she sighs)
I think I'll go to sleep. This has  been a busy day. (picking up her paper  bag)
My luggage. She smiles, takes out a flowered muumuu, holds it up to A
Pretty. Did you get that at  Brinkmeyer's? Melanie nods and drapes the muumuu over her arm. She is s for a moment, pensive. Then:
Do you think I should go?
That's up to you.
It's really up to Lydia, isn't it?
Never mind Lydia. Do you want to go?
(firmly)
Yes.
Then go. The room is silent. Melanie nods, slowly, and then smiles
Thank you, Annie. Suddenly, into the silence, comes a THUMP at the door,  startling them both.
(rising)
Who can that be at this hour? (she walks to door)
Who is it? (no answer)
Is someone there? Melanie goes to stand beside Annie. Puzzled, Annie unlock the door, and then opens it. She looks out into the night There is nothing but the SOUND of the wind.
(to the emptiness  outside)
Is anyone there?
(pointing to the ground)
Look.
(sympathetically)
Ohhh. Oh, the poor thing. He probably  lost his way in the dark.
who stares at the dead bird as Annie stoops to pick it up And then, slowly:
But... it isn't dark, Annie.  There's  a full moon.
as Annie, stooping, looks up at her. On their puzzlement consternation:

HIGH SHOT - THE BRENNER HOUSE The place is decorated with balloons strung from the house to various points on the l The children, in party clothes, with their parents, are  clustered around a long folding table upon which are  sandwiches, ice cream and soft drinks. The parents are ei helping the children to more or telling them they are hav too much. There is a general SOUND of kid's CHATTER and  LAUGHTER. Coming up the sloping path, away from the party are Melanie and Mitch. The CAMERA PANS them UP the slope away from the party in background. The CAMERA PANS them as they come near to us and, once mo the party is in the background. Mitch and Melanie pass th CAMERA out to the left.

Melanie and Mitch come INTO the picture from the right an stand against the sky. Mitch takes a martini shaker from of his pockets, and two glasses from the other. He hands of the glasses to Melanie, and then pours.
I really shouldn't have any more.   I'm a little tipsy already.
I'm trying to get you to stay for  dinner. We're going to have a lot of  roast left over.
I couldn't possibly. I have to get  back.
(with a shrug)
Cheers.
Cheers. They drink.
What's in this? Nitro-glycerin?
Why do you have to rush off? What's  so important in San Francisco?
Well... I have to get to work tomorrow  morning, for one thing.
(surprised)
You have a job?
(sipping at the martini)
I have several jobs.
What do you do?
I do different things on different  days.
Like what?
(hesitating)
On Mondays and Wednesdays, I work  for the Travelers' Aid. At the  airport.
Helping travelers.
Yes. She hesitates for a moment, thinking. She has never reall considered before what she does with her time, and now th she is accounting for it, it sounds a little meaningless unimportant.
And on Tuesdays, I take a course in  General Semantics at Berkeley.  That's  not a job, of course. I just take it  because...
What about Thursdays and Fridays?
On Thursdays I have my meeting and  lunch. (pause)
I'm chairman of a group that's sending  a little Korean boy through school.   We plan how to raise funds and...  things like that. (she shrugs)
And Fridays? What do you do then?
Nothing. (she smiles)
I go to bird shops on Fridays.
I'm glad you do.
Do you know what I was doing in that  shop?
What?
I have an aunt, you see. Aunt Tessa.  She's seventy years old, and veddy  prim and strait-laced. (she does an imitation)
She's coming back from Europe at the  end of the month, and I'm going to  give her a myna bird that'll talk to  her.
What'll it say?
(facetiously)
You'll think me very bold, sir.
No, tell me. She leans over and whispers in his ear. They both burst o LAUGHTER. But then suddenly, a very serious look comes in Melanie's face.
serious, introspective.
That's silly, isn't it?  Teaching a  bird to shock my aunt. That's just  silly and childish. (slight pause)
Maybe I ought to go join the other  children.

as she moves abruptly away from him, and starts toward wh the children have begun playing Blind Man's Bluff. seen from Cathy's position. He flies off, cycles and then returns.

against the sky, flying away in formation.

as the children begin drifting back toward the table and cake. There is the curious feeling of lighting having str very close by without having injured anyone. All that  adrenaline has boiled up, and now it has no place to go.

rushing to Lydia, swinging the cloth at her head. She is  hysterics now, BABBLING. The SHRIEK of the birds is a wil cacophony.

A shambles. Windows broken, furniture knocked over, pictu askew, the floor covered with birds and broken glass. In corner of the room, Lydia crouches with her hands coverin her face, sobbing. The burnt curtain is still smoldering. Mitch is covered with soot. Melanie puts down the broom  wearily. The attack is over.
reaching down to pick up a dead bird.
a plain man with a limited intelligence, used to giving o speeding tickets or warning drunks. He holds the bird on palm of his hand, looks at it steadily, nodding all the w
That's a chimney swift, all right.
We know what it is, Al.
Lydia is huddled in one of the easy chairs, still in shoc
Well, these birds live in chimneys,  you know.
Not by the thousands.
No, I gotta admit this is peculiar. (pause)
Did you have a light burning or  something.
Yes, but the curtains were drawn.
'Cause sometimes birds are attracted  by light, you know. (pause)
Sure is a peculiar thing.
What are we going to do about it,  Al?
I don't think I get you, Mitch. Do  about what?
Well... (he feels a little  foolish)
Well... these birds attacked us.
slight disbelief on his face.
What's more likely, they got in the  room and was just panicked, that's  all.
(still a little  hesitant)
All right, I'll grant you a bird'll  panic in an enclosed room. But, they  didn't just get in. They came in!  Right down that chimney.
(trying to make sense  of this)
My wife found a bird in the back  seat of her car once.
(shrugs)
Didn't know how he got in there.   Had a broken leg, turned out. Just  fluttering all around there. (he shrugs again)
These birds were...
What I'm trying to say, Mitch, is  these things happen sometimes, you  know? Ain't much we can do about it. (he shrugs)
Tell him about the party.
That's right. We had a party here  this afternoon for Cathy. Her  birthday.
Oh, yeah, yeah. (he grins)
How old is she now?
Eleven. In the middle of the party,  some gulls came down at the children.  And Miss Daniels was attacked by a  gull just yesterday after...
considering this.
Yeah. (thinking)

Were the kids bothering them or  something? 'Cause sometimes they'll  do that, you know. If you make any  kind of disturbance near them, they'll  just come after you. I seen that  plenty of times myself.
The children were playing a game,  Al. Those gulls attacked without...

Now, Lydia, 'attack' is a pretty  strong word, don't you think? I mean,  birds just don't go around attacking  people without no reason, you know  what I mean? The kids just probably  scared them, that's all.
These birds attacked!
(nodding)
Well, what would you like me to do,  Lydia? Put out a pick up and hold on  any suspicious birds in the area? (he smiles)
Now, that'd be pretty silly, wouldn't  it?
Does this room look silly?
No, you got quite a mess here, I'll  admit that. (pause)
Maybe you oughta put some screening  on top of your chimney (pause)
Seems a little pointless, though.   Freak accident like this wouldn't  happen again in a million years. (pause)
You want some help cleaning up?
exasperated.
I can handle it myself.
giving a small moan.
I'll take Cathy up to bed.
Are you staying?
I think I should, don't you?
observing, making no comment.
putting her arm around Cathy's shoulders.

as Cathy and Melanie go out.
Well, if there's anything else I can  do, Mitch...

Goodnight, Lydia. No answer.
Sure is peculiar, I got to say that  for it. He exits.
It is silent. Mitch looks across at Lydia who sits as sti as a stone in her chair. The door closes gently on a note utter helplessness.

Melanie has just gotten out of bed. She is wearing the ra unsophisticated nightdress she brought at the store.  Her hair is loose. She wears no makeup. She is bent over a  lavatory which has been installed in the bedroom. She is  busily brushing her teeth. Her head half turns as she HEA VOICES.

Okay.

No. Melanie finished brushing her teeth. She goes to the wind and looks out. Outside, we HEAR the SOUND of the pickup t starting. turning from the window. She goes to the bedroom door, CA FOLLOWING. She opens the door.

Mitch?
coming down the steps from the attic room. The house is e The CAMERA FOLLOWS her into the dining room, where she st at the cage of lovebirds, bends down to them with a smile her face.

leaving the cage. She walks to the sideboard upon which i an electric coffee percolator which is plugged into the w She feels it with her hand. It is hot. She pours a cup, t peers out of the side window. LONG SHOT - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch on the shore, working with a rake in his hands. A t column of smoke is climbing the sky.
carrying the cup of coffee. She sets it down for a moment put on her fur coat, which is hanging on the hall stand. picks up the cup again, walks to the front door and EXITS

as Melanie scans the horizon. There isn't a bird anywhere sight. The day is still and clear, but somehow ominous in its silence. Her gaze comes to rest on Mitch and the thin column of smoke again. In the distance, Mitch sees her an raises his arm in greeting. She waves back at him. He put the rake down and begins walking toward the house.

closer to the house now.
waiting, anticipating.

as first surprised, and then puzzled. The back screen DOO CLATTERS shut off screen. A small hurt look crosses her f

as she turns away from the house and begins walking in th garden, sipping idly at her coffee. A screen DOOR CLATTER again. She turns. Mitch is coming out of the house, from the front door, we a different shirt, buttoning it as he walks to her.
I wanted to change my shirt. Melanie is uncomprehending.

(nodding)

I think I've got it all figured out,  by the way.
Really? Tell me about it.
(secretively)
It's an uprising.
Of birds?
Certainly, of birds. Mitch grins.

It all started several months ago  with a peasant sparrow up in the  hills, a malcontent. He went around  telling all the other sparrows that  human beings weren't fit to rule  this planet, preaching wherever anyone  would listen...
Growing a beard...
(delighted)
Yes, of course, he had to have a  beard! 'Birds of the world, unite!'  he kept saying, over and over...
So they united.
Not at first. Oh yes, a few sparrows  out for kicks...
Well, they'll go along with anything.
Sure. But eventually, even the more  serious-minded birds began to listen.   "Why should humans rule?" they asked themselves.
Hear!
Why should we submit ourselves to  their domination?
Hear, hear!
And all the while, that sparrow was  getting in his little messages.   Birds of the world, unite!
Take wing!
You have nothing to lose but your  feathers. They both burst out laughing, then fall into silence, the laugh again and finally are silent. The garden is deathly still.
(attempting to be  serious)
What it was, probably...
Mmm?

They're probably hungry, that's all.   This was a bad summer. They eat  berries and... and nuts, you know,  and the hills are all burned out, so  they're probably searching for food  wherever they can get it.
With my little sparrow leading team. She laughs, and Mitch joins her, but it is hollow this ti Like children who have told themselves a too realistic ho story, they are becoming a little frightened.
It's so damn quiet out there.
It was like that yesterday.
What do you mean?
After the gulls attacked.
I hadn't thought of that. (pause)
And then the swifts came.
It makes you feel as if they're...  they're waiting or... resting...  or....
(trying to make it  light again)
No, they're having a meeting, Melanie.  Your sparrow is standing on a soap  box and...
her face dead serious.
...waving his little wings... His voice trails. His face becomes serious, too. Again, t garden is silent.
her face set and grim, her eyes serious, her words coming slowly and with the chill of horror on them.
They were angry, Mitch. They came  out of the chimney in fury. (pause)
I had the feeling they wanted each  and every one of us dead.

Melanie, Melanie...
I'm frightened, Mitch.
No, no...
I'm frightened and confused and I...  I think I want to go back to San  Francisco where there are buildings  and... and concrete and...
Melanie...

Oh damn it, why did you have to walk  into that shop? They kiss suddenly and fiercely. On their kiss,
